verses.text: Whoever isolates himself seeks his own desire; he breaks out against all sound judgment.
verses.comment: This verse stresses the dangers of isolation and self-will, highlighting the importance of community and submission to wise counsel—a concept reinforced in the New Testament exhortation to gather together (Heb. 10:25).

verses.text: A fool takes no pleasure in understanding, but only in expressing his own opinion.
verses.comment: This contrasts the wise, who listen and gain understanding, with the foolish, who are self-focused. It reinforces the value of humility and teachability.

verses.text: When wickedness comes, so does contempt, and with dishonor comes disgrace.
verses.comment: Evil actions lead to public shame and disgrace. This ties into the biblical principle that sin brings suffering not only spiritually but also in reputation and relationships.

verses.text: The words of a man’s mouth are deep waters; the fountain of wisdom is a flowing stream.
verses.comment: Just as water sustains life, so wise words bring refreshment and blessing. Jesus’ claim to give living water (John 4:14) is a fulfillment of this spiritual wisdom.

verses.text: To show partiality to the wicked is not good, nor to deprive the innocent of justice.
verses.comment: Justice that is unbiased is a biblical value. Both Old and New Testaments affirm this principle, pointing towards a moral law grounded in divine order.

verses.text: A fool’s lips walk into strife, and his mouth invites a beating.
verses.comment: Careless speech often leads to trouble and consequences. This warning encourages self-control of the tongue (cf. James 3:5-10).

verses.text: A fool's mouth is his ruin, and his lips are a snare to his soul.
verses.comment: The destructive power of words is rooted in the human heart. Speech reveals one’s spiritual condition and can bring judgment.

verses.text: The words of a whisperer are like tasty morsels; they go down into the inner parts of the body.
verses.comment: Gossip can appear appealing but is inwardly corrupting. This calls for vigilance lest sinful words take root internally.

verses.text: Whoever is slack in his work is a brother to him who destroys.
verses.comment: Negligence is equated with active harm. This wisdom underscores communal duty and the value of diligent stewardship over one’s responsibilities.

verses.text: The name of the LORD is a strong tower; the righteous run to it and are safe.
verses.comment: The covenant name of God stands as a security for the faithful, prefiguring refuge found in Christ for the New Covenant people. Strong spiritual protection is available to those who trust in the Lord.

verses.text: A rich man’s wealth is his fortified city, and like a high wall in his own imagination.
verses.comment: Trust in riches is a false security, contrasted sharply with reliance on the Lord in the previous verse. Material comfort can give an illusion of invulnerability.

verses.text: Before destruction a man's heart is haughty, but humility comes before honor.
verses.comment: This recurring theme in Proverbs and the teachings of Jesus shows God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble.

verses.text: If one gives an answer before he hears, it is folly and shame.
verses.comment: Listening before speaking is wisdom. The parallel in James 1:19 shows this is an enduring mark of the virtuous life.

verses.text: A man's spirit will endure sickness, but a crushed spirit who can bear?
verses.comment: Spiritual strength sustains in weakness, hinting at the holistic view of salvation: healing is not only physical, but also emotional and spiritual.

verses.text: An intelligent heart acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.
verses.comment: Desire for wisdom is a mark of the righteous. This pattern appears throughout Scripture, emphasizing the pursuit of truth through reason and revelation.

verses.text: A man's gift makes room for him and brings him before great men.
verses.comment: Generosity and proper use of gifts often lead to opportunities. Gifts here can mean both talents and material offerings.

verses.text: The one who states his case first seems right, until the other comes and examines him.
verses.comment: Hearing both sides before judgment is underscored in biblical law, prefiguring just approaches to settling disputes in the Christian community.

verses.text: Casting lots puts an end to quarrels and decides between powerful contenders.
verses.comment: Here, as elsewhere, decision-making by lot is seen as God’s providence guiding even in uncertain situations. The early apostles used this method showing continuity with ancient wisdom.

verses.text: A brother offended is more unyielding than a fortified city, and disputes are like the bars of a castle.
verses.comment: Relational discord, even among close brethren, can become difficult to mend. This highlights the wisdom of pursuing reconciliation quickly (cf. Matt. 5:23-24).

verses.text: From the fruit of a man's mouth his stomach is filled; he is satisfied by the harvest of his lips.
verses.comment: Words not only impact others but also return to bless or harm the speaker. The biblical teaching of sowing and reaping also applies to speech.

verses.text: Death and life are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruit.
verses.comment: Speech has spiritual consequences—a mysterious power over life and death, a concept Jesus affirms (Matt. 12:36-37) and the apostles echo.

verses.text: He who finds a wife finds a good thing and obtains favor from the LORD.
verses.comment: Marriage is depicted as a divine gift, affirming the dignity and goodness of the marital union, a foreshadowing of the mystery in Ephesians 5:32.

verses.text: The poor use entreaties, but the rich answer harshly.
verses.comment: Economic disparity affects relationships and attitudes. The Scriptures call for mercy and humility, especially from the wealthy toward the poor.

verses.text: One with many companions may come to ruin, but there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
verses.comment: Faithful friendship is more valuable than mere popularity. This hints at the spiritual friend par excellence, fulfilled in the self-giving friendship of Christ (John 15:13).
